title: Chapter V: Exercise 1 - Part 3
text:
Big Question
How did sediment delivery to ancient coastlines vary across the Phanerozoic, and what controls these changes?

title: Chapter V: Exercise 1 - Part 3
text:
What You Will Do
You will estimate sediment flux at river outlets through deep time using paleogeography, hydrology, and climate data from the Palaeo Data Cube. Starting with one time slice, you will: 1. Identify major river outlets near ancient coastlines. 2. Compute basin attributes (area, relief, temperature). 3. Apply the BQART equation to estimate sediment flux.
Then, you will scale up your workflow to compare two time slices and finally analyze trends across the entire Phanerozoic.

title: Chapter V: Exercise 1 - Part 3
text:
Why This Matters
Sediment flux is a key link between tectonics, climate, and the carbon cycle. Understanding how sediment delivery changed through time helps explain ocean chemistry, nutrient cycles, and even long-term climate regulation.

title: Chapter V: Exercise 1 - Part 3
text:
Your Tasks

Single Snapshot Analysis:
1.1. Load paleogeography, flow direction, flow accumulation, and temperature for one time slice (e.g., 100 Ma).
1.2. Identify outlets near coastlines using flow accumulation and land/ocean mask.
1.3. Compute basin attributes: drainage area, relief, mean temperature.
1.4. Apply BQART to estimate sediment flux at each outlet.
1.5. Visualize sediment flux on a global map.
Compare Two Worlds
2.1. Repeat for another time slice (e.g., 250 Ma).
2.2. Compare sediment flux patterns and discuss differences.
Deep-Time Trends
3.1. Automate your workflow for all Phanerozoic slices.
3.2. Plot time series of global sediment flux and interpret major trends.

title: Chapter V: Exercise 1 - Part 3
text:
Skills You Will Gain

Advanced raster analysis and hydrological modeling in Python.
Basin delineation and outlet detection using flow direction and accumulation.
Applying empirical models (BQART) to paleodata.
Visualizing spatial patterns and temporal trends.

title: Chapter V: Exercise 1 - Part 3
text:
Points for Discussion
Which factors (area, relief, temperature) most strongly influence sediment flux?
How does paleogeography control sediment routing?
What assumptions did you make about outlet selection and basin delineation?
How do tectonic and climate changes explain sediment flux trends?

title: Chapter III: Exercise 1 - Part 1
text:
How did Earth look 100 million years ago, and how has its geography changed over hundreds of millions of years?



In this module, you will:

Start simple: Explore a single paleogeographic map and visualize Earth at 100 Ma.
Compare worlds: Compute and interpret differences in land and ocean distribution between two time slices.
Go deep time: Extend your analysis to the entire Phanerozoic (last 540 million years) and identify major trends.




Earth’s geography controls climate, ocean circulation, and biodiversity. By reconstructing these changes, you’ll learn how scientists use data and coding to answer fundamental questions about our planet’s history.




Find the data: Locate paleogeographic GeoTIFF files in the Palaeo Data Cube repository.
Load and inspect: Read raster data in Python, check metadata, and understand its structure.
Compute basic stats:
3.1. Land vs. ocean fraction for a chosen time slice.
3.2. Differences between two slices.
3.3. A time series of land fraction across the Phanerozoic.
Visualize:
4.1 Global maps using matplotlib and cartopy.
4.2. A trend plot showing how land/ocean distribution evolved.





Working with GeoTIFFs in Python (rasterio, numpy).
Performing basic geospatial analysis (masking, counting, area-aware calculations).
Creating global maps and time-series plots.
Automating workflows for multi-step analysis.




What assumptions did you make when defining land vs. ocean?
How does using pixel counts vs. area-aware calculations affect your results?
What patterns do you see in land fraction across the Phanerozoic? Any surprises?

title: Chapter III: Exercise 1 - Part 2
text:
Big Question
Did faster spreading rates in the past lead to younger seafloor and thinner lithosphere? How did crustal architecture evolve through time?

title: Chapter III: Exercise 1 - Part 2
text:
What You Will Do
You will test a geodynamic hypothesis using multiple paleogeographic and structural datasets from the Palaeo Data Cube. Starting with one time slice, you will:

Map seafloor age, crustal thickness, and lithospheric thickness.
Compute global averages and distributions.
Compare two time slices to see if patterns change.
Finally, you will extend your analysis to the entire Phanerozoic and visualize trends.

title: Chapter III: Exercise 1 - Part 2
text:
Why It Matters
The age and thickness of Earth’s oceanic crust and lithosphere reflect plate tectonic processes and mantle dynamics. Understanding these changes helps explain supercontinent cycles, ocean basin evolution, and even long-term climate regulation.

title: Chapter III: Exercise 1 - Part 2
text:
Your Tasks

Single Snapshot Analysis:
1.1. Load seafloor age, crustal thickness, and lithospheric thickness for one time slice (e.g., 100 Ma).
1.2. Compute mean values and visualize maps.
1.3. Plot histograms of seafloor age distribution.
Compare Two Worlds:
2.1. Repeat for another time slice (e.g., 250 Ma).
2.2. Compare averages and distributions.
2.3. Discuss whether the data supports faster spreading at one time.
Deep-Time Trends:
3.1. Automate your workflow for all Phanerozoic slices.
3.2. Plot time series of mean seafloor age, crustal thickness, and lithospheric thickness.
3.3. Interpret major trends and link them to tectonic events.

title: Chapter III: Exercise 1 - Part 2
text:
Skills You Will Gain

Handling multiple raster datasets in Python.
Computing global and zonal statistics.
Visualizing maps, histograms, and time-series plots.
Testing hypotheses with real geoscience data.

title: Chapter III: Exercise 1 - Part 2
text:
Points for Discussion
Does the data support the idea that faster spreading rates lead to younger seafloor?
How do crustal and lithospheric thickness trends relate to supercontinent cycles?
What assumptions did you make about data interpretation and resolution?
What uncertainties exist in these reconstructions?
